content.description:
Damocles is the obvious pillar that can be seen lower on Mt Wilson from the road just before Rampart Creek Hostel heading south on the Icefield Parkway. The pillar up and to the right is Cadeau Cache.

There is some confusion around documentation of this route, and Seven Pillars of Wisdom. It appears Damocles and that route are essentially one and the same, and spotty record keeping in the 80s resulted in two routes that have similar descriptions. 

For the purposes of this entry, and how climbers have come to know these routes, I am putting in Damocles as the one pitch pillar and Seven Pillars of Wisdom will include the entire 7 pitches of climbing up the gully system. 

The Beta

Climb one approach pitch of 40 meters of WI3ish ice that can't be seen from the road, slog your way uphill bypassing a likely dry cliff band on the left to get to the base of the obvious pillar.

Fight your way up the 20 meter pillar which forms overhanging ice at the top and makes for deceptively hard and committing moves to pull over the lip. Belay off of trees up and right.



A few minutes north of the Rampart Creek Hostel, you can see it from the road.

Park outside of the avalanche area on the shoulder, approach from the drainage on the left and cross over into the drainage that contains the climb. Snowshoes or skis recommended, ~45 minutes to the base of the approach pitch. 

Standard rack.

A fun pitch of WI4 leads to a good belay ledge on the right, at the base of the first steep pillar. The second pitch climbs through several vertical sections of mostly good ice, but it can be hollow at times. After about 40 meters, the difficulty eases off, but the ice gets thinner at the top out. Park 6.8k from the David Thompson Highway intersection, where a small drainage comes down from the right. Hike up the drainage about 1000 feet, until it intersects a larger drainage coming in from the right. At this point, cross and head up the steep slope, eventually trending left.

As you continue working your way through the pines up and left, you will eventually see the route. Continue up and left through the pines and alders until you are on the right side of the Chaos drainage. Cross this drainage and continue up the left side to the base of a 5m ice step. Climb the ice and continue up the gully to the base of the route. An hour forty five in good conditions. Lots of snow, much longer. Screws for protection and belay anchors, and some chord for rap anchors.

There is a large block about 25' back from the top of the route, that can be slung for a rappel anchor. The ice is generally thin at the top.

climbs.name: Ice Nine
climbs.fa: 1974, Adrian and Alan Burgess, Bugs McKeith

content.description:
Ice Nine is an impressive looking pillar just south of Rampart Creek Hostel.  The first pitch climbs up a free standing pillar for 45m.  The 2nd pitch is the crux and can be an actual pillar or just a maze of icicles.  It is a full 50m to the very top.  Some parties elect to rappel from the ice just before the lip but there are a few smaller trees that have rappel cord up and right from the top out (as of Mar 2020).  It has been said that the first pitch has a nasty habit of falling down without warning in March after a few days of warm sunny weather.  Go early when it is still freezing and plan to be off by the time it warms up.

The climb sits in the obvious drainage 1km south of Rampart Creek Hostel.  Park along the road and walk up the avalanche gully to the base (about 45min)  The route is the left of a pair of climbs, with the right one being Happy Days.
Ice screws.  Bolted anchors at the top of pitch 1 on the left.

climbs.name: Oh Le Tabernac
climbs.fa: Carlos Buhler and Dick Renshaw, Jan 1981

content.description:
Steep climbing with gorgeous views of the peaks lining the Saskatchewan River. The right side stays drier than the left but you will likely have options of a couple pillars for the first half, then a wide curtain to a ledge. If continuing to climbs above, traverse left here, otherwise, rappel 60m from a bolted anchor on the right (high above the ice, a couple mixed moves mandatory).



On the south side of Mt Wilson and visible as you come around Murchison and drop into Saskatchewan River Crossing. Park 2.1km north of the turn for the David Thompson highway. Head through trees for ten or fifteen minutes until you hit open slopes with a view of the climb. Straight up the avy debris gets you to the base.

Screws

climbs.name: Seven Pillars of Wisdom
climbs.fa: Barry Blanchard and Troy Kirwan, Feb 1992

content.description:
Seven Pillars of Wisdom is essentially climbing the Damocles pillar and then continuing upwards for 5 more pitches of ice to where the drainage opens up to a slope below the ridge.

Due to spotty record keeping there is overlap between this route and Damocles and it seems they are essentially the same route. For the purpose of this entry, Seven Pillars of Wisdom will refer to the entire route.

P1: Climb one approach pitch of 40 meters of WI3ish ice that can't be seen from the road, slog your way uphill bypassing a likely dry cliff band on the left to get to the base of the obvious pillar.

P2: Fight your way up the 20 meter Damocles pillar which forms overhanging ice at the top and makes for deceptively hard and committing moves to pull over the lip. Belay off of trees up and right.

P3: This pitch is apparently often missing, it is a WI2/3 step when in, but if it's out don't despair. It goes at M4/5 and we climbed it with a rack of nuts, a pecker and a couple of pitons. Belayed on pitons off a rock outcrop on the left, but a tree on the right would work too.

P4: Fun 40 meters of continuous WI3/4 followed by snow slogging.

P5: Easy 15 meter step of WI2 ice followed by a lot of snow slogging to the final two pitches.

P5&6: The bottom of these final pitches was out for us and the rock was terrible and unprotectable to get to the ice, so we bailed here. According to other reports this is about 100 meters of WI4 ice that thins out to steeper WI5 at the top. 

Descend creatively off of trees and v threads. There is not much tat here given how obscure this route is and no bolts at all.



A few minutes north of the Rampart Creek Hostel, you can see it from the road.

Park outside of the avalanche area on the shoulder, approach from the drainage on the left and cross over into the drainage that contains the climb. Snowshoes or skis recommended, ~45 minutes to the base of the approach pitch. 

Standard ice rack, a rack of nuts and some pitons and peckers if the 3rd pitch is out.

Slaughter House is the incredibly impressive mixed route directly behind Ice Nine. 



It starts directly behind the Ice Nine pillar on the lookers right side, climbs through the roof, and joins the ice.

Bolts, and screws.
Mount Wilson dominates the landscape just north of the Saskatchewan River crossing, where the Parkway intersects with the David Thompson Highway.  It is home to dozens of fine ice and mixed routes.
